author: sfgate.com
title: Recommended books, Oct. 11
text:
We recommend these recently reviewed books: 
Gold Fame Citrus 
By Claire Vaye Watkins 
(Riverhead; 342 pages; $27.95)
With razor-sharp language and an eye for the devastating detail, Watkins, in her debut novel, conjures up a California whose water supply has dwindled down to nothing.
M Train 
By Patti Smith 
(Knopf; pages; $25)
Smith’s captivating follow-up to her memoir “Just Kids” takes us on a journey through the “stuff” of Smith’s bookshelves and suitcases, as well as of her mind and memory.
Tangled Vines 
Greed, Murder, Obsession and an Arsonist in the Vineyards of California
By Frances Dinkelspiel
(St. Martin’s Press; 302 pages; $26.99)
If the disparate story lines in Dinkelspiel’s book can be said to have a central theme, we might call it the ephemeral nature of wine — its fundamental susceptibility to destruction, whether by flame, fraud or tectonics. 
When the Sick Rule the World 
By Dodie Bellamy 
(Semiotext(e); 247 pages; $15.95 paperback)
Bellamy’s essay collection covers a wide range of topics, including environmental illness, Occupy Oakland poets, Salem witch trials, 1970s Marin lesbians and Twitter-induced gentrification.
